comments.body:
No, I tried that, but if I make the constructor const, then on the line where the contents are const, it wants a const constructor to be used:
```dart
components.add(const _ComponentTuple('code', <String>[]));
```
But then at runtime it throws because I'm modifying the contents of an unmodifiable list. It works if I leave off the const, but the analyzer complains then. So, since I can't use the const anyhow, I decided to not make the tuple be const.

I was thinking that you probably actually want to write it in the main.dart, since this class doesn't have all of the metadata available. But, if you want to write it here (which makes sense, other than the metadata not being available), you could pass in a Map with the data in it from the main.

I don't mind moving it - I couldn't see what metadata we wanted so didn't know where it existed. I'll move it to `main.dart` and add the metadata I can see (package, library, element names), but if there should be a range in there too, let me know where I can find (or calculate) it.

Actually, I'll leave it inside for now simple because the filename may be passed in as null and generated itself, and I'd rather not duplicate that logic outside to keep the filenames the same (should it ever change), and I'll pass in a map (though lmk if you'd prefer the opposite).
Pushed a change for this - we pass a map in with the things we have in main (id, package, library, element) and then add to it inside where we can have other info (like the filename being used).

Instead of it only having an effect if the type is `application`, you should have it exit in `main` with an error if `--dartpad` is specified, but the type isn't application.  Failing silently is bad here, since it'll just zoom past it in the doc creation, any nobody will ever notice until they look at the broken docs.

This function should also have the same assert as above:
```dart
  assert(!showDartPad || type == SnippetType.application, 'Only application snippets work with dartpad.');
```
Definitely a good idea. Made both of these changes.
